issues.description: The problem statement contains an internal contradiction about the type of the Animal.name attribute: the UML shows the attribute as type String (problem_statement.md, UML line showing "- name: String"), while the textual instructions explicitly require using StringBuilder for the name to enable efficient modifications. This inner contradiction can confuse students about which type to use when implementing Animal and its getter/setter.
issues.suggested_fix: Resolve the contradiction in the problem statement. Either (A) update the UML to declare name: StringBuilder so the UML and text agree that the attribute is a StringBuilder, or (B) remove the special StringBuilder instruction from the text and consistently require a String name. Prefer option (A) if the exercise intends to teach StringBuilder usage; update all example code and wording to reflect StringBuilder (and indicate expected getter/setter types), otherwise prefer option (B).

issues.description: The provided reference solution implements Animal.name as a String (private String name; and getName()/setName(String)), but the problem statement explicitly instructs students to use StringBuilder for the name attribute. This mismatch between specification and the solution repository is structural and may mislead students (they will follow the specification but then see a differing reference implementation).
issues.suggested_fix: Make the reference implementation match the specification. If the assignment requires StringBuilder, modify solution/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Animal.java so the name field is a StringBuilder, update the constructor and get/set methods to use/return StringBuilder (or provide both getName()/getNameBuilder() as appropriate), and adjust any code that uses getName() to call toString() where a String is required (e.g., in messageOnRide/messageOnMilk implementations). Alternatively, if the solution's use of String is intentional, update the problem text to remove the StringBuilder requirement so all artifacts are consistent.

issues.description: The problem text explicitly instructs students to use a StringBuilder for the Animal 'name' attribute (“Important: ... use StringBuilder for the name attribute”), while the UML in the same problem statement shows the attribute as name: String and the solution implementation (Animal.java) uses a private String name with String-typed getter/setter. This is an unintentional semantic inconsistency about the same conceptual entity (the Animal's name) across artifacts and creates confusion for students: they are told to implement the attribute using StringBuilder but the reference solution and UML indicate a plain String, and the template Main uses constructors that pass String literals. Students may waste time deciding which representation to use or implement code incompatible with tests or the provided solution.
issues.suggested_fix:
Resolve the mismatch so all artifacts describe the same representation for the Animal.name attribute. Two acceptable fixes (pick one and apply consistently):

1) If StringBuilder was intentional: update the UML and solution/template code to use StringBuilder for the name attribute (e.g., private StringBuilder name; public StringBuilder getName(); public void setName(StringBuilder name) OR keep getName()/setName() returning/accepting String but store internally as StringBuilder—document the choice). Update constructors and any call sites (Main and tests) to construct/convert accordingly.

2) If String was intended (simpler/consistent with UML and solution): remove or correct the textual instruction that requires StringBuilder in the problem statement so it instructs using String (or does not mandate StringBuilder). Ensure the problem statement, UML, template comments, and solution are all aligned on 'String' for the name attribute.

Make sure the chosen representation is reflected in example code in Main, the UML, and the exercise text so students have a single, unambiguous target to implement.
